page.title: 04FARMING IN CODICOTE/WELWYN
page.content: This area is traditionally a barley growing and malt producing region. Until quite recently cereal production on the higher ground was supplemented by dairy or mixed farming in the river valley. However economic factors resulting from the Common Agricultural Policy of the E.E.C. have caused farmers to concentrate on cereals so that today, farming in this area is devoted almost entirely to the growing of barley and wheat. Occasionally rape seed is grown for the production of vegetable oil. Modern agricultural machinery enables large farms to be run with a very small labour force. The use of large tractor-ploughs and combine harvesters has encouraged the destruction of hedgerows to make larger fields. Modern equipment including grain dryers minimises harvesting delays
